knife 0.5.0 documentation

knife.lazy.lazyknife — Lazily evaluated combo knife

«  knife.active.sliceknife — Actively evaluated slicing knife   ::   Contents   ::   knife.lazy.cmpknife — Lazily evaluated comparing knife  »

knife.lazy.lazyknife — Lazily evaluated combo knife¶

class knife.lazy.lazyknife(*things, **kw)¶

Lazily evaluated combo knife.

Combines features from every other knife knife.

all()¶

Discover if worker() is True for every incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> __(2, 4, 6, 8).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).all().get()
True
any()¶

Discover if worker() is True for any incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(1, 4, 5, 9).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).any().get()
True
append(*things)¶

Insert things after other incoming things.

Parameters:things – incoming things
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> __(3, 4, 5).append(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[3, 4, 5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
argmap(merge=False)¶

Feed each incoming thing to worker() as wildcard positional arguments.

Parameters:merge (boolean) – merge global positional params() with positional arguments derived from incoming things
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> # default behavior
>>> test = __((1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4))
>>> test.worker(lambda x, y: x * y).argmap().get()
[2, 6, 12]
>>> # merge global positional arguments with iterable arguments
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x, y, z, a, b: x * y * z * a * b).params(7, 8, 9).argmap(merge=True).get()
[1008, 3024, 6048]
ascii(errors='strict')¶

byte encode() outgoing things with the 'ascii' codec.

Parameters:errors (string) – error handling for decoding issues
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from stuf.six import u, b
>>> test = __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,))
>>> test.ascii().oneach().peek()
['[1]', 'True', 't', 'i', 'g', 'None', '(1,)']
at(n, default=None)¶

Slice off incoming thing found at index n.

Parameters:
  • n (integer) – index of some incoming thing
  • default – default returned if nothing is found at n
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> from knife import __
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).at(2).get()
3
>>> # return default value if nothing found at index
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).at(10, 11).get()
11
attrs(*names)¶

Collect attribute values from incoming things that match an attribute name found in names.

Parameters:names (string) – attribute names
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> from stuf import stuf
>>> stooge = [
...    stuf(name='moe', age=40),
...    stuf(name='larry', age=50),
...    stuf(name='curly', age=60),
... ]
>>> __(*stooge).attrs('name').get()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> # multiple attribute names
>>> __(*stooge).attrs('name', 'age').get()
[('moe', 40), ('larry', 50), ('curly', 60)]
>>> # no attrs named 'place'
>>> __(*stooge).attrs('place').get()
[]
average()¶

Discover average value among incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> __(10, 40, 45).average().get()
31.666666666666668
back()¶

Switch back to the previous knife object that piped its incoming things through this knife.

baseline()¶

Restore incoming things to baseline snapshot().

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> undone.snapshot().append(1).append(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1, 2]
>>> undone.baseline().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
bytes(encoding='utf-8', errors='strict')¶

byte encode() outgoing things.

Parameters:
  • encoding (string) – Unicode encoding
  • errors (string) – error handling for encoding issues
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> test = __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,))
>>> test.bytes().oneach().peek()
['[1]', 'True', 't', 'i', 'g', 'None', '(1,)']
choice()¶

Randomly slice off one incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).choice().get() 
3
clear()¶

Clear everything.

Return type:self (a knife object)
combinate(n)¶

Discover combinations for every n incoming things.

Parameters:n (integer) – number of incoming things to generate combinations from
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> __(40, 50, 60).combinate(2).get()
[(40, 50), (40, 60), (50, 60)]
copy()¶

Duplicate (by deep copying) each incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __([[1, [2, 3]], [4, [5, 6]]]).copy().get()
[[1, [2, 3]], [4, [5, 6]]]
count()¶

Discover how common each incoming thing is.

Collects tuple of (least common thing, most common thing, [counts of everything (a list of tuple pairs of (thing, count))]).

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> common = __(11, 3, 5, 11, 7, 3, 5, 11).count().get()
>>> # least common thing
>>> common.least
7
>>> # most common thing
>>> common.most
11
>>> # total count for every thing
>>> common.overall
[(11, 3), (3, 2), (5, 2), (7, 1)]
dice(n, fill=None)¶

Slice one iterable incoming thing into n iterable incoming things.

Parameters:
  • n (integer) – number of incoming things per slice
  • fill – value to pad out incomplete iterables
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> __('moe', 'larry', 'curly', 30, 40, 50, True).dice(2, 'x').get()
[('moe', 'larry'), ('curly', 30), (40, 50), (True, 'x')]
difference(symmetric=False)¶

Discover difference within a series of iterable incoming things.

Parameters:symmetric (boolean) – use symmetric difference
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default behavior
>>> test = __([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], [5, 2, 10], [10, 11, 2])
>>> test.difference().get()
[1, 3, 4]
>>> # symmetric difference
>>> test.original().difference(symmetric=True).get()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 11]
duality()¶

Divide incoming things into two iterables, the first everything worker() is True for and the second everything worker() is False for.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> test = __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
>>> divide = test.duality().get()
>>> divide.true
[2, 4, 6]
>>> divide.false
[1, 3, 5]
filter(invert=False)¶

Collect incoming things matched by worker().

Parameters:invert (boolean) – collect things worker() is False rather than True for
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # filter for true values
>>> test = __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0)
>>> test.filter().get()
[2, 4, 6]
>>> # filter for false values
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).filter(invert=True).get()
[1, 3, 5]
first(n=0)¶

Slice off n things from the starting end of incoming things or just the first incoming thing.

Parameters:n (integer) – number of incoming things
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).first().get()
5
>>> # first things from index 0 to 2
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).first(2).get()
[5, 4]
flatten()¶

Reduce nested incoming things to flattened incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> __([[1, [2], [3, [[4]]]], 'here']).flatten().get()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 'here']
get()¶

Return outgoing things wrapped with wrap().

If there’s only one outgoing thing, only that thing will be returned. If there are multiple outgoing things, they will be returned wrapped with wrap().

group()¶

Group incoming things using worker() as the key function.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> from knife import __
>>> # default grouping
>>> __(1.3, 2.1).group().get()
[Group(keys=1.3, groups=(1.3,)), Group(keys=2.1, groups=(2.1,))]
>>> from math import floor
>>> # use worker for key function
>>> __(1.3, 2.1, 2.4).worker(floor).group().get()
[Group(keys=1.0, groups=(1.3,)), Group(keys=2.0, groups=(2.1, 2.4))]
initial()¶

Slice off everything except the last incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).initial().get()
[5, 4, 3, 2]
intersection()¶

Discover intersection within a series of iterable incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __([1, 2, 3], [101, 2, 1, 10], [2, 1]).intersection().get()
[1, 2]
invoke(name)¶

Call method name from each incoming thing with the global positional and keyword params().

The original thing is kept if the return value of the method call is None.

Parameters:name (string) – method name
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # invoke list.index()
>>> __([5, 1, 7], [3, 2, 1]).params(1).invoke('index').get()
[1, 2]
>>> # invoke list.sort() but return sorted list instead of None
>>> __([5, 1, 7], [3, 2, 1]).invoke('sort').get()
[[1, 5, 7], [1, 2, 3]]
items(*keys)¶

Collect values from incoming things (usually sequences or mappings) that match a key found in keys.

Parameters:keys (string) – keys or indices
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> stooge = [
...    dict(name='moe', age=40),
...    dict(name='larry', age=50),
...    dict(name='curly', age=60)
... ]
>>> # get items from mappings like dictionaries, etc...
>>> __(*stooge).items('name').get()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> __(*stooge).items('name', 'age').get()
[('moe', 40), ('larry', 50), ('curly', 60)]
>>> # get items from sequences like lists, tuples, etc...
>>> stooge = [['moe', 40], ['larry', 50], ['curly', 60]]
>>> __(*stooge).items(0).get()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> __(*stooge).items(1).get()
[40, 50, 60]
>>> __(*stooge).items('place').get()
[]
kwargmap(merge=False)¶

Feed each incoming thing as a tuple of wildcard positional and keyword arguments to worker().

Parameters:merge (boolean) – merge global positional or keyword params() with positional and keyword arguments derived from an incoming things into a single tuple of wildcard positional and keyword arguments like (iterable_args + global_args, global_kwargs + iterable_kwargs)
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default behavior
>>> test = __(
...  ((1, 2), {'a': 2}), ((2, 3), {'a': 2}), ((3, 4), {'a': 2})
... )
>>> def tester(*args, **kw):
...    return sum(args) * sum(kw.values())
>>> test.worker(tester).kwargmap().get()
[6, 10, 14]
>>> # merging global and iterable derived positional and keyword args
>>> test.original().worker(tester).params(1, 2, 3, b=5, w=10, y=13).kwargmap(merge=True).get()
[270, 330, 390]
last(n=0)¶

Slice off n things from the tail end of incoming things or just the last incoming thing.

Parameters:n (integer) – number of incoming things
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).last().get()
1
>>> # fetch last two things
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).last(2).get()
[2, 1]
map()¶

Feed each incoming thing to worker().

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x: x * 3).map().get()
[3, 6, 9]
mapping(keys=False, values=False)¶

Run worker() on incoming mapping things.

Parameters:
  • keys (boolean) – collect mapping keys only
  • values (boolean) – collect mapping values only
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> # filter items
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).worker(lambda x, y: x * y).mapping().get()
[2, 6, 12, 2, 6, 12]
>>> # mapping keys only
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).mapping(keys=True).get()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # mapping values only
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).mapping(values=True).get()
[2, 3, 4, 2, 3, 4]
max()¶

Discover maximum value among incoming things using worker() as the key function.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 4).max().get()
4
>>> stooges = (
...    {'name': 'moe', 'age': 40},
...    {'name': 'larry', 'age': 50},
...    {'name': 'curly', 'age': 60},
... )
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(*stooges).worker(lambda x: x['age']).max().get()
{'age': 60, 'name': 'curly'}
median()¶

Discover median value among incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(4, 5, 7, 2, 1).median().get()
4
>>> __(4, 5, 7, 2, 1, 8).median().get()
4.5
merge()¶

Reduce multiple iterable incoming things into one iterable incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(['moe', 'larry'], [30, 40], [True, False]).merge().get()
['moe', 'larry', 30, 40, True, False]
min()¶

Discover minimum value among incoming things using worker() as the key function.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> test = __(10, 5, 100, 2, 1000)
>>> test.min().get()
2
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x: x % 100 == 0).min().get()
10
minmax()¶

Discover minimum and maximum values among incoming things.

Collects namedtuple (minimum value, maximum value).

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> minmax = __(1, 2, 4).minmax().get()
>>> minmax.min
1
>>> minmax.max
4
oneach()¶

Toggle whether each outgoing thing should be individually wrapped with wrap() or whether all outgoing things should be wrapped with wrap() all at once.

Default behavior is to wrap() everything at once. The default behavior is reverted to after get() or peek() is invoked.

Return type:self (a knife object)
original()¶

Restore incoming things to original snapshot.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> undone.original().peek()
[1, 2, 3]
params(*args, **kw)¶

Assign positional and keyword arguments used when worker() is invoked.

Return type:self (a knife object)
pattern(pattern, type='parse', flags=0)¶

Compile search pattern for use as worker().

Global positional and keywordparams() are reset when a pattern is compiled.

Parameters:
  • pattern (string) – search pattern
  • type (string) – engine to compile pattern with. Valid options are ‘parse’, ‘re’, or ‘glob’
  • flags (integer) – regular expression flags
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> # using parse expression
>>> test = __('first test', 'second test', 'third test')
>>> test.pattern('first {}').filter().get()
'first test'
>>> # using glob pattern
>>> test.original().pattern('second*', type='glob').filter().get()
'second test'
>>> # using regular expression
>>> test.original().pattern('third .', type='regex').filter().get()
'third test'
peek()¶

Preview current incoming things wrapped with wrap().

If there’s only one outgoing thing, only that thing will be returned. If there are multiple outgoing things, they will be returned wrapped with wrap().

permutate(n)¶

Discover permutations for every n incoming things.

Parameters:n (integer) – number of incoming things to generate permutations from
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(40, 50, 60).permutate(2).get()
[(40, 50), (40, 60), (50, 40), (50, 60), (60, 40), (60, 50)]
pipe(knife)¶

Pipe incoming things through another knife.

Parameters:knife – another knife
prepend(*things)¶

Insert things before other incoming things.

Parameters:things – incoming things
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(3, 4, 5).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 3, 4, 5]
range()¶

Discover length of the smallest interval that can contain the value of every incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(3, 5, 7, 3, 11).range().get()
8
reduce(initial=None, reverse=False)¶

Reduce iterable incoming things down to one incoming thing using worker().

Return type:

self (a knife object)
Parameters:
  • initial – starting value
  • reverse (boolean) – reduce from the right side of incoming things
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> # reduce from left side
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce().get()
6
>>> # reduce from left side with initial value
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce(initial=1).get()
7
>>> # reduce from right side
>>> test = __([0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5]).worker(lambda x, y: x + y)
>>> test.reduce(reverse=True).get()
[4, 5, 2, 3, 0, 1]
>>> # reduce from right side with initial value
>>> test.original().worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce([0, 0], True).get()
[4, 5, 2, 3, 0, 1, 0, 0]
repeat(n=None, call=False)¶

Repeat either incoming things or invoke worker() n times.

Parameters:
  • n (integer) – number of times to repeat
  • call (boolean) – repeat results of invoking worker()
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> # repeat iterable
>>> __(40, 50, 60).repeat(3).get()
[(40, 50, 60), (40, 50, 60), (40, 50, 60)]
>>> def test(*args):
...    return list(args)
>>> # with worker
>>> __(40, 50, 60).worker(test).repeat(n=3, call=True).get()
[[40, 50, 60], [40, 50, 60], [40, 50, 60]]
rest()¶

Slice off everything except the first incoming thing.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).rest().get()
[4, 3, 2, 1]
reverse()¶

Reverse the order of incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).reverse().get()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
sample(n)¶

Randomly slice off n incoming things.

Parameters:n (integer) – sample size
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).sample(3).get() 
[2, 4, 5]
shuffle()¶

Randomly sort incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object)
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).shuffle().get() 
[3, 1, 5, 4, 2]
slice(start, stop=False, step=False)¶

Take a slice out of incoming things.

Parameters:
  • start (integer) – starting index of slice
  • stop (integer) – stopping index of slice
  • step (integer) – size of step in slice
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> # slice from index 0 to 3
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2).get()
[5, 4]
>>> # slice from index 2 to 4
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2, 4).get()
[3, 2]
>>> # slice from index 2 to 4 with 2 steps
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2, 4, 2).get()
3
snapshot()¶

Take baseline snapshot of current incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object)
sort()¶

Reorder incoming things using worker() as the key function.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default sort
>>> __(4, 6, 65, 3, 63, 2, 4).sort().get()
[2, 3, 4, 4, 6, 63, 65]
>>> from math import sin
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(sin).sort().get()
[5, 4, 6, 3, 1, 2]
sum(start=0, precision=False)¶

Discover total value of adding start and incoming things together.

Parameters:
  • start (integer or float) – starting number
  • precision (boolean) – add floats with extended precision
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 3).sum().get()
6
>>> # with a starting mumber
>>> __(1, 2, 3).sum(start=1).get()
7
>>> # add floating points with extended precision
>>> __(.1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1).sum(precision=True).get()
0.8
traverse(invert=False)¶

Collect deeply nested values from incoming things matched by worker().

Parameters:invert (boolean) – collect things that worker() is False rather than True for
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> class stooge:
...    name = 'moe'
...    age = 40
>>> class stooge2:
...    name = 'larry'
...    age = 50
>>> class stooge3:
...    name = 'curly'
...    age = 60
...    class stooge4(object):
...        name = 'beastly'
...        age = 969
>>> def test(x):
...    if x[0] == 'name':
...        return True
...    elif x[0].startswith('__'):
...        return True
...    return False
>>> # using worker while filtering for False values
>>> __(stooge, stooge2, stooge3).worker(test).traverse(invert=True).get() 
[ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge'), ('age', 40)])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge2'), ('age', 50)])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge3'), ('age', 60)]),
OrderedDict([('age', 969), ('classname', 'stooge4')]))]
undo(snapshot=0)¶

Restore incoming things to a previous snapshot.

A snapshot of incoming things is automatically taken at the start of each knife operation.

Parameters:snapshot (integer) – number of steps ago 1, 2, 3, etc.
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # undo back one step
>>> undone.append(1).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # undo back one step
>>> undone.append(1).append(2).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
>>> # undo back 2 steps
>>> undone.append(1).append(2).undo(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
unicode(encoding='utf-8', errors='strict')¶

unicode (str under Python 3) decode() outgoing things.

Parameters:
  • encoding (string) – Unicode encoding
  • errors (string) – error handling for decoding issues
Return type:

self (a knife object)

 
>>> test = __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,))
>>> test.unicode().oneach().peek()
[u'[1]', u'True', u't', u'i', u'g', u'None', u'(1,)']
union()¶

Discover union within a series of iterable incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __([1, 2, 3], [101, 2, 1, 10], [2, 1]).union().get()
[1, 10, 3, 2, 101]
unique()¶

Discover unique incoming things.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4).unique().get()
[1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4).worker(round).unique().get()
[1, 2, 3, 4]
worker(worker)¶

Assign callable used to work on incoming things.

Global positional and keyword params() are reset when new worker is assigned.

Parameters:worker – a callable
Return type:self (a knife object)
wrap(wrapper)¶

Assign object, type, or class used to wrap outgoing things.

Default wrapper is list. The default wrapper is reverted to after get() or peek() is invoked.

Parameters:wrapper – an object, type, or class
Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).wrap(tuple).peek()
(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
zip()¶

Convert multiple iterable incoming things to tuples composed of things found at the same index position within the original iterables.

Return type:self (a knife object) 
>>> test = __(['moe', 'larry'], [30, 40], [True, False])
>>> test.zip().get()
[('moe', 30, True), ('larry', 40, False)]
